body: The Travis build indicates failure after running for almost 7 hours, but when looking at the log output it indicates success. Any thoughts on what happened?
I saw that. It makes no sense. The Travis log shows a successful 21 minute build. I think the problem is with Travis and delays starting the build and problems with their time tracking.
Thanks! I assumed there was some Travis issue, just not sure what.
They had a message about unusual backlog and delays on container-based infrastructure. My guess is that this is related. I restarted the build to see if anything changed.
Appreciate it!
I am going merge this
Thanks, @keith-turner
Merge in d99592c

My last update limits the methods which remain undeprecated from the superclass by replacing `getBoolean(String, bool)` with a new `hasSasl()` which was the only actual use of this method and is much cleaner.

My intent is to squash and merge this in today, rename the 1.8 branch to 1.9, and then drop the deprecated stuff in the 2.0 branch... assuming there's no further feedback on this change.
Changes in this PR merged in 518c109.  I did some minor fixups of unit test in 591c3a0dc9d3ba0eb12cba2328e8e5badc6c7f60
I believe the code is ready to be merged.  I am going to merge this into the 1.7, 1.8, and 2.0 (master) branches.

Changes so far are causing errors in TCompactProxyIT because it reuses table names.  I think we need a unit test to pin point where exactly the cache needs to cleared where it did not have to previously.
Should ACCUMULO-4731 be closed now?
I applied these changes to 1.7, and merged into 1.8 and subsequently into master
merged in cf9e754b045e3fac452df282bcf4ec97974038a0
Merged 7bc630cdce4a0aa02be4873e2873ff1036a94e14
@ctubbsii Thanks for the review!  Updated per your comments.

> Good find. I think we should apply this back to the 1.7 branch, and use try-with-resources to properly close the input stream under all cases.

+1 to that.

I'm curious: why did findbugs not catch this? Anyone look at that yet? I thought our use of findbugs was rather rigorous.

> why did findbugs not catch this?

Probably because the resource is being allocated by a method... like a factory pattern. Unclosed resources allocated that way are difficult to track. It probably shows up in Eclipse as "potential resource leak", but that warning is usually suppressed with default Eclipse settings, because it's pretty spammy and full of false positives, because Java does not have a good way to track resource from factories.
Latest cache implementation is looking promising.  Sunny day ITs were passing on Friday.  I am now looking if I can use my JMH benchmark repo to measure any performance gains.

Measuring this branch against 1.7.3 using MiniAccumuloCluster with 100 tables.  I created 3 tests that call Tables.getTableId(), tableOperations.tableIdMap() and tableOperations.exists().  Each of these methods are commonly used and shouldn't hinder performance with 2 being from the API and one a common internal method. 

1.7.3 Results:
Benchmark                     Mode  Cnt     Score     Error  Units
TablesBenchmark.getExists    thrpt   50  5293.911 ± 127.073  ops/s
TablesBenchmark.getTableId   thrpt   50  5356.971 ± 127.876  ops/s
TablesBenchmark.getTableMap  thrpt   50  5239.343 ± 137.264  ops/s

ACCUMULO-4778 branch:
Benchmark                     Mode  Cnt        Score       Error  Units
TablesBenchmark.getExists    thrpt   50   917886.356 ± 16067.502  ops/s
TablesBenchmark.getTableId   thrpt   50  1696546.994 ± 26953.792  ops/s
TablesBenchmark.getTableMap  thrpt   50  1718777.835 ± 21612.689  ops/s

Test: TablesBenchmark.getExists showed 17238.5% increase in ops/s
Test: TablesBenchmark.getTableId showed 31569.9% increase in ops/s
Test: TablesBenchmark.getTableMap showed 32705.2% increase in ops/s
Total average 27171.21% increase in ops/s
Ahh, the two-hop makes it hard to follow. Thanks, I didn't think about that.
Running the benchmark tests with multiple threads only shows a greater improvement.  I think this is ready to merge.

For future reference, I pushed the tests I created to my accumulo-benchmark repo: https://github.com/milleruntime/accumulo-benchmark/blob/master/jmh-test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/TablesBenchmark.java
Looks good to me.  Does the command line help print the new options?  I've worked with the shell some but can't remember how it prints the usage.
Yep, I updated the createtable help usage to display the new options.
I pushed another commit.  I think this PR is no longer a WIP and is ready for review.  There is more that I want to do for the Connector builder but that can be done in later issues.
@adamjshook Were there additional changes, unrelated to the original issue also done in your updated commits? It seems like a larger change was made, but I'm having trouble following it.

@ctubbsii The `try-with-resources` caused an indentation change that makes it look larger and I moved a large block of code into a new method to make it more readable.  The summary of the changes are:

1. Added a `try-with-resources` in the [`replicateRFiles`](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbR324) and [`replicateLogs`](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbR369)
2. Moved [processing of the WAL header](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbL374) into [`getWalStream`](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbR685).
3. Moving the exceptions that would be thrown from `getInputStream` [here](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbL327) and [here](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbL378) down to the bottom of the `try-with-resources`.
4. Refactoring [this](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/53c0e4ffd9083a7dc13c0d93c65b6a081da0cf56/server/tserver/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/tserver/replication/AccumuloReplicaSystem.java#L332) block of code into a [`processBatches`](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/369/files#diff-48d2b9734f0e624e93e136f24f35e0bbR384) method.

Ah, it was the relocation to a new method that screwed me up. If you ignore whitespace, the regular diff without that change is much better. To ignore whitespace in the GitHub.com view, add `?w=1` to the end of the diff URL.
To do a diff on the command-line with git, just do: `git diff --ignore-all-space`

>To ignore whitespace in the GitHub.com view, add ?w=1 to the end of the diff URL.

TIL 🙌
Commits squashed and commited into 1.7, 1.8, and master
I rebased these changes to 1.8
hi @keith-turner, have you had a chance to review the latest updates? Are there any other comments/suggestions on the ticket or is it ready to merge?
Any more changes left for this or are we good to merge?
Could you give a description of the solution?  Seems different than the one purposed in the JIRA ticket.

When I got into the code I noticed it only needed to create these file refs in the case of bulk loaded files with logical time set.  So it seemed quick to check for that case only create file refs if those types of files exists.
Gotcha!  Looks good to me.  I like the simple solution.

@adamjshook I'd like to update my review, but with the code relocations, I'm still having trouble following it. If you could update the code to undo the relocations, so a clean diff, ignoring whitespace, can be viewed, I could update my review.
@ctubbsii @keith-turner Undo on the code relocations and applied Keith's suggestion to refactor out the `FSDataInputStream`.  Back to you!

@ghajos thanks for the contribution.  Would you like to be added to the Accumulo [people page](http://accumulo.apache.org/people/)?  If so let me know what info you would like or make a PR to the [website repo](https://github.com/apache/accumulo-website).
@keith-turner  @ctubbsii Thank you for the review!
I know there was some uncertainty with changing this debug information in 1.8... was there something that brought you to a decision?  I am just wondering what your final thoughts were...

In 702276816b, I modified how `ZookeeperInstance` is created internally for the new API. This avoids calls to `loadDefault` of `ClientConfiguration`.  I tested locally and I don't see any `no client.conf`log mesages anymore.
Is there a particular process for merging in fixes and applying them to other release lines?
Created [ACCUMULO-4815](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-4815) to track some cleanup efforts.

> Is there a particular process for merging in fixes and applying them to other release lines?

No hard+fast rules. General recommendation is to apply it to the oldest branch and then merge it through newer release lines.
@joshelser Thanks!  Looks like I don't have write access here on Github.  Is that a mistake or should I apply it via `gitbox.apache.org`?
Try  following https://gitbox.apache.org/setup/ @adamjshook
Created follow-on issue for the potentially unclosed crypto stream from `DfsLogger.readHeaderAndReturnStream` https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-4816

> I know there was some uncertainty with changing this debug information in 1.8... was there something that brought you to a decision? I am just wondering what your final thoughts were...

It was the magnitude of the performance impact.  For lots of really small lookups I was seeing the code spend 10% to 15% of its time creating this thread name.  With this change, it hardly shows up.  So my thinking was the thread names still has some useful info, but its much faster to create now.
Merged in eb15e45
@joshelser what's the state here?
Need to revisit again. Got sidetracked by other stuff.
@bfach10, this is pretty nice addition to Accumulo. It would be great to get it committed. Let me know if you need any help.
This PR was never merged into the code base and its corresponding JIRA issue remains open.

Changed max to min.

Unfortunately ACCUMULO-4413 is a duplicate of ACCUMULO-3807. Should I create a new pull request for that ticket? Also there are some concerns about this issue under ACCUMULO-3807 this modification should follow, but don't know how yet.

This seems to be OK for me. Ran TestIngest locally against Apache Hadoop 3.0.0.

Big changes that were required:
* Start bundling all of the commons-\* jars we already depending on but expected Hadoop to give us (yay, wart removal)
* Also have to include htrace-core4 as this one isn't shaded by Hadoop as it would break. htrace3 and 4 are currently bundled because it's going to be a re-working of our entire tracing infra to support htrace4 (I think). I've punted on it.
* bootstrap_configuration.sh is updated, as is the template for Hadoop3
Hrm, I broke hadoop2 compilation?
We could update the travis configuration to execute once with hadoop2, and once with hadoop3. It'd be useful to see both.

> I'm assuming most of the new assembly components file is identical to the old one, but for the bundled dependency changes

There are only the dependency additions that have already been mentioned here.

> We used to have an enforcer rule that guaranteed hadoop.profile had a valid value. That might be good to add back in now that we're reintroducing the property.

Will look here too.

> does Accumulo need recompiling or just repackaging to switch between Hadoop 2 and 3? Obviously, you can't build against Hadoop 3 without using Java 8.

I've not noticed any required recompilation.

>> does Accumulo need recompiling or just repackaging to switch between Hadoop 2 and 3?
>
> I've not noticed any required recompilation.

If no recompilation is needed, I wonder if it would be a good idea to just go ahead and build both assemblies, regardless of which profile is set? Or, if the hadoop3 assembly works fine with hadoop2, maybe we can just always build that one? (I never liked relying on picking up the libs shipped by Hadoop anyway.)

@ghajos  I'll go ahead and change the title of this PR now to point to 3807. If you want to edit the log message to change it to 3807, that's fine. Otherwise, a committer can do it before merging, leaving you to focus on the changeset, which is the important part :smile_cat: .

> If no recompilation is needed, I wonder if it would be a good idea to just go ahead and build both assemblies, regardless of which profile is set?

Let's tack this on as a follow-up. I don't wanna hold up the basic build stuff for something more advanced.

> (I never liked relying on picking up the libs shipped by Hadoop anyway.)

Oh, funny. I thought you were the proponent of it :)

I think there would be troubles getting a single assembly that worked with H2 and H3 given the commons-configuration clashes you already worked around. But, maybe there's a way... just doesn't seem super high-priority to me.

> Let's tack this on as a follow-up.

Agreed.

> Oh, funny. I thought you were the proponent of it :)

You may have gotten that impression because I'm against bundling. But, I'm also against using Hadoop's bundled libs for same reason I'm against bundling our own. I'm in favor of intentional and thoughtful dependency convergence, as a downstream activity. I'd actually prefer we not ship any binary tarball packaging... but since we do, we might as well do it in a way that works well for most users. In any case, I agree with you, this can be improved once we get the basics in. :smile_cat:
Also, you happy with this in the current state, @ctubbsii? For `master` right now, I suppose (can consider a cherry-pick earlier too). Any opinions from the rest of the folks?

@joshelser This PR is against the 1.8 branch already. I don't see any reason it should be merged only into master. It can go into the 1.8 branch so we can have some Hadoop 3 support for Accumulo 1.9.0. There's no real risk in 1.9.0, since these changes are only build tooling / packaging changes.
Primo. Thanks for the feedback, boss. Will merge this about shortly.
Changes applied to 1.7, and merged into 1.8 and master

Does this revert the behavior that ACCUMULO-4574 was trying to address - if the table is online, return and do not wait for additional actions? The original behavior would block if there was a fate operation on the table and online was called - the original fix was to not block and return because the table was online and no additional actions were required to be in online.

If the table is online - why do we need to wait?

With this change, if the table is already online then the FATE operation is not called.  However if the method parameter `wait == true` then it will scan the metadata table waiting for all tablets to be assigned. The table below shows the new behavior. 

| Table state | Wait parameter | Fate called | Scan metadata table unil all tablets assigned
| ---------------|----------------------|-----------------|----------------------------------------------------------
| ONLINE | true | No | Yes
| ONLINE | false | No | No
| OFFLINE | true | Yes | Yes
| OFFLINE | false | Yes | No

Scanning the metadata table until all tablet assigned is a client side operation that does not block on FATE locks.

Before the change the behavior was :

| Table state | Wait parameter | Fate called | Scan metadata table unil all tablets assigned
| ---------------|----------------------|-----------------|----------------------------------------------------------
| ONLINE | true | No | **No**
| ONLINE | false | No | No
| OFFLINE | true | Yes | Yes
| OFFLINE | false | Yes | No

Bumping to the newer version results in errors about "Corrupted STDOUT". I'll leave the existing fix in place for now, rather than revert.
